title: Let's talk about what's ACTUALLY wrong with Yasuo
body:
I see a lot of Yasuo QQ threads and I'm kind of tired of seeing "omg rito he does so much damage + cc + mobility wtf nerf nao" and it's like uh. That's not where his hidden power is, and that's not why he's broken.

Reason 1 that Yasuo has tons of hidden power: Wonky spaghetti code windwall. If Yasuo times his W correctly, he can place it in any direction and it will block ANY projectile coming towards him, regardless of direction. The reason? Windwall has a hitbox has soon as Yasuo casts the spell, and the instant he casts it this hitbox intersects with Yasuo's, making him 100% immune to projectiles. The fix? Windwall has no hitbox until it is fully formed. This means Windwall is no longer a "oh god I heard the Sona ult sound effect lemme mash W in any direction to stop it" spell, and a calculated block. Still just as effective at blocking long range skillshots, less effective at blocking instantcast or skillshots from fog. COUNTERPLAY!

Reason 2 that Yasuo has tons of hidden power: Double passive. Yasuo has both a shield and double crit from his passive. Yes, his crits are weaker, but double crit at level 1 is pretty silly (as instanced by the brawler's glove 20% crit infinite sustain w/ warlord's bloodlust before the hotfix). Having 100% crit at 1 and a half items is ridiculous, especially when one of those items is Shiv (since you're guaranteed a shiv crit every time it procs). The fix? Put his crit on an ability (preferably W) so that Yasuo has to scale into his crit. 20%/40%/60%/80%/100% additional crit per rank. Gives him a reason to rank up windwall if he's snowballing while simultaneously forcing him to choose to delay his damage from abilities. Also, unless Yasuo ranks it up first, this locks him out of insane crit levels until the midgame, making his laning phase much less oppressive.

Nothing else about Yasuo's kit is the problem. It's not his E. It's not his ult. Those things, by themselves, are fine. But in combination with his ridiculous safety and low decision making requirements (due to W being such a reaction-based spell due to the hitbox interaction explained above), he also scales into damage very, very quickly (only requiring about 3k gold to hit 100% crit on live). The changes outlined above would make his laning phase less oppressive while retaining his mid-game teamfighting spikes and lategame damage spikes (which are not really where the problem is unless he's snowballed from lane, which these changes would address).

tl;dr: take the hidden power off of W and put crit passive on another ability to help Yasuo's kit be less overloaded and give him less for free instead of just flat nerfing him.

Regarding the fact that the Wind Wall totally deletes {{champion:267}} ult, what if her ult was coded so that it was a few, separate chunks of water that ran right next to each other? The only effect this would have on gameplay is if a Wind Wall blocks it, where it would only block the part that is the size of the wall itself and the other parts would run off to the sides and still work.

For Vitriolic's specific case (Sona Ult getting blocked from the opposite side of the wall) I don't think the size is so much the problem; even if it was extremely narrow, if its spawning "on top of" Yasuo it seems likely to cause this problem.

I don't know to what degree they intended for it to be forgiving in terms of cast time; I know there have been times that I've cast the wall when it should have been too late to block the projectile (the projectile was visually behind the wall by the time the wall "formed") but because of hitboxes, it blocked it since it starts at his position and then sort of "floats" forward. Of the two options mentioned:  1) move its spawn point to just in front of Yasuo, in the direction it is cast. Enough so that the opposite side of Yasuo's hitbox is not protected at the start of the cast. This would be a nerf, for sure, but I think it'd "feel" better for both Yasuo's opponents (who can feel like they properly outmaneuvered him) and Yasuo himself (who should know that he cast it the wrong direction) without it feeling unfair to either party.

The other option would be 2) what you suggested as for making it only block in one direction. This is a much larger nerf, as part of Yasuo's strength (especially against ranged champs) is being able to duck back and forth across the wall as the opponent dances around it. Personally I like it because it emphasizes positioning, but it does come with drawbacks. Even if the wall spawned "forward" of Yasuo, in those cases where he cast it the wrong direction it could still stop the ability - such as with, say, Ezreal's Ultimate - from continuing past his position and hitting his teammates.

IMHO I think that if you went with #1, putting the spawn point just a tad further forward, it would eliminate accidental cases of protecting Yasuo when he misclicks his wall, but still give him the option of, "Oh $#!* I'm too late to block that from me, but I can still protect a teammate" by casting it "behind" him if the projectile gotten too close.

There is a disconnect, in some ways, between the sort of "word logic" versus "code logic" of how CC works. For example, Yasuo's Ultimate does specify that he can target "**Airborne**" enemies, but it is often misunderstood by players what that means. Airborne =/= "Knockup". Airborne is basically coded as any CC with two components: a stun (so you can't use abilities, move or attack during it) and a "Move Block", which is part of the ability's code but basically means forced movement (or forced lack of movement, in the case of Suspended targets).

This means that Knock Ups (Alistair), Knock Backs (Janna), Knock Asides (Draven) are all "Airborne" effects. Some of these make "word logic" sense, such as Singed's Fling. Sure, he is actually *throwing* them over his shoulder and they are visually in the air, so that all works. However Pulls are actually coded as an Airborne effect, since they are made of 1) a stun and 2) forced movement, or a Move Block. This means that yes, Thresh can trigger Yasuo's Ultimate on both "tugs" of his Q in addition to his E. This makes less "logic" sense from a visual perspective. But its not accidental, its not a coding error, its all correct and functioning as intended.

If Yasuo's ult only functioned on actual, true 'n' blue "knockups" it'd hurt his power considerably and could cause its own set of problems (for example Nami, who you mentioned, can "Knock Up" on her Ultimate, but her Stun is actually a Suspension effect, not a knockup.)

This way, you can still make the same kind of last-second blocks that other, normal shield spells can do, but it does require you to actually aim the Wind Wall correctly.

To Reason 2: I just want to say that having multiple passives **is never a valid complaint**. Champions have had multiple passives or ultra-versatile passives since the dawn of the League.

I wish you could recognize that the point of these changes wouldn't be to flat nerf Yasuo. I wish people weren't so ignorant that they could see these things.

CURRENTLY, Yasuo is in a really crap spot as a character because he consistently gets nerfed whenever he becomes strong due to how overwhelming it is to play against him. These changes would be targetted at lowering the oppressiveness of his early game without affecting his mid and late game power spikes - THIS WOULD MAKE YASUO ~EASIER~ TO BUFF BECAUSE HIS MATCHUPS WOULDN'T BE AS OPPRESSIVE. 

The point of these changes is not to gut the character. The point of making changes to the character in general should not be to gut the character. But pretending that Yasuo should just get buffed because "oh he's weak" is ignorant - everyone knows how Yasuo goes. Either he's useless or he's in every game. This behavior is the hallmark of an overloaded kit. By redistributing his power budget a bit, you allow the character's numbers to go up. Currently Yasuo is the only character in the game with a steroid that is 100% "activated" at level 1 - and this takes up a surprising amount of his power budget. But is it REALLY worth to double your crit at level 1 if it means that all your numbers have to be shit and your character has to be weaker than it really should be because as soon as you finish Shiv you have tons of crit? Do you REALLY think that having 100% crit at level 9 is integral to the character succeeding? Because I really don't think there's a big problem with delaying Yasuo's powerspike from a 3k gold 100% crit spike completely independent of level to, say a level 13 spike.

I never said I thought Yasuo was overpowered. I never said I thought he was even strong right now. But if they redistributed power budget on his kit, they could BUFF Yasuo without catapulting him into OPness. That's the entire point of these kinds of changes - you change where he spikes so that the character can be good without being oppressive. Currently if Yasuo is strong there are too many matchups mid that he just wins outright, so he has to be kept in a very awkward state where nobody is really happy - Yasuo players are unhappy with how weak he feels when he doesn't snowball, and people playing against Yasuo get frustrated when you beat him in lane and then he gets 2-3 kills from other lanes (or farms the jungle or splitpushes for 5 minutes or WHATEVER), hits 100% crit, and comes into your lane and destroys you. He's a character who has a powerspike that is basically impossible to delay, because it's only dependent on him getting a tiny amount of gold (what's the REAL harm in delaying the 100% crit spike for a couple levels AFTER you get the items for it? Aside from making it way less oppressive to play against, there's little change in Yasuo's teamfighting in the mid or late game).

Wind Wall has no reason to last more than a fraction of a second. It was intended to be a "cut down projectiles" type of ability in the first place, but that was eventually made into Wind Wall because the concept was apparently too difficult to code. Right now it's used more as a zoning tool than a reactive counter to projectiles.

Cut its duration down to .5 to 1 second, similar to Fiora's Riposte, and make it spawn just slightly off of Yasuo's hitbox so that only projectiles from one direction are blocked right at the instant it's cast.

Distinguo: how could the lowered duration have been difficult to code? What you're thinking about is the projectile **slowing field**, which they say was hard to code and not worth since it needed to be OP to be noticeable.
